repnme.cdata!: Thailand - Lam Takhong Pump Storage Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated as
            satisfactory, and sustainability is likely. Bank performance
            overall is considered as fully satisfactory, while Borrower
            performance overall is judged as highly satisfactory.
            Lessons learned are as follows: Large pump storage schemes
            can be constructed at much lower than hitherto imagined
            capital costs and could provide an economic source of
            peaking power for systems in which surplus off-peak energy
            can be drawn from large efficient thermal or combined cycle
            plants. Globalization, leading to large international
            equipment suppliers moving manufacturing to their facilities
            in developing countries could pose equipment quality and
            delivery problems. An efficient buttress needs to be set up
            in the implementing agency's project management
            resources to counter claims made by civil contractors.
            Equipment and construction contractor problems could delay
            otherwise well-designed and managed hydropower projects.
            Beside these technical lessons, economic/financial lessons
            included: Sudden economic/financial crisis, especially in a
            country that has been experiencing a prolonged period of
            growth, could severely impact power demand and render large,
            long gestation power development schemes uneconomic in
            comparison to (otherwise less economic) smaller ones. Under
            crisis conditions, utilities need to exercise great
            financial discipline, drastically cut down operating
            expenses, and strike an appropriate balance between
            curtailing and carrying on with investments.

18225752.projn: TH-Lam Takhong Pump Storage Project -- P004799
18225752.admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific

repnme.cdata!: Thailand - Lam Takhong Pump Storage Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Lam Takhong Pump Storage Project
            will: (a) assist the Electricity Generating Authority of
            Thailand (EGAT) in optimizing its investment decisions and
            help meet the system's peak power demand from 2000
            onwards at least cost; (b) strengthen the environmental
            capabilities of EGAT; and (c) assist the Government in
            privatization of the generation, transmission and
            distribution utilities. In addition, the Bank expects,
            during the project's tenure, to continue rendering
            technical advice to the Government in the implementation of
            power sub-sector and environmental reforms.

repnme.cdata!:
Thailand - Lam Takhong Pump Storage Project
            : environmental impact assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The environmental assessment covers five
            areas affected by the project: 1) Lam Tan Khong reservoir
            and its vicinity; 2) the proposed right bank alternatives
            sites for the reservoir; 3) the proposed left bank
            alternative site for upper reservoir; 4) downstream
            irrigation area; and 5) Nakhon Ratchasima urban area and
            districts in the vicity.  The assessment study was conducted
            on the four major environmental resources and values as
            stipulated by the National Environmental Board (NEB),
            namely: 1) physical resources; 2) ecological resources; 3)
            human use values; and 4) quality of life values.  The study
            covered all of the above areas according to their direct and
            indirect environmental relationships with the project.  In
            addition, environmental economics were analyzed.
